editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A chaste maid in Cheapside. A pleasant conceited comedy never before printed. As it hath been often acted at the swan on the Bankside, by the lady Elizabeth her servants.
London, printed for Francis Constable dwelling at the sign of the crane in Paul's churchyard. 1630.

div.head: The names of the principal persons.

list.item: Sir Walter whorehound, a suitor to Moll.
Sir Oliver Kixe, and his wife, kin to sirwalt.
Mr. Allwit, and his wife, whom sirwalt. keeps.
Tuchwood senior, and his wife, a decayed gentleman.
Tuchwood junior, another suitor to Moll.

div.head: Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter Maudlin and Moll, a shop being discovered.

sp.speaker: Maudline.
sp.p: Have you played over all your old lessons o'the virginals?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes, you are a dull maid o'late, methinks you had need have somewhat to quicken your green sickness, do you weep? A husband. Had not such a piece of flesh been ordained, what had us wives been good for? To make salads, or else cried up and down for sampire. To see the difference of these seasons, when I was of your youth, I was lightsome, and quick, two years before I was married. You fit for a knight's bed, drowsy browed, dull eyed, drossy spirited, I hold my life you have forgotten your dancing: when was the dancer with you?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: The last week.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Last week, when I was of your board, he missed me not a night, I was kept at it, I took delight to learn, and he to teach me, pretty brown gentleman, he took pleasure in my company, but you are dull, nothing comes nimbly from you, you dance like a plumber's daughter, and deserve two thousand pound in lead to your marriage, and not in goldsmith's ware.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Now what's the din betwixt mother and daughter, ha?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Faith small, telling your daughter marry of her errors.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Errors, nay the city cannot hold you wife, but you must needs fetch words from Westminster, I ha' done i'faith, has no attorney's clerk been here a late, and changed his half-crown-piece his mother sent him, or rather cozened you with a guilded twopence, to bring the word in fashion, for her faults or cracks, in duty and obedience, term 'em eeve so sweet wife. As there is no woman made without a flaw, your purest lawns have frays, and cambrics bracks.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: But 'tis a husband solders up all cracks.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: What is he come sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Sir Walters come.

He was met at Holborn bridge, and in his company, a proper fair young gentlewoman, which I guess by her red hair, and other rank descriptions, to be his landed niece, brought out of Wales, which Tim our son (The Cambridge boy) must marry.
'Tis a match of sir Welter's own making to bind us to him, and our heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: We are honoured then, if this baggage would be humble, and kiss him with devotion when he enters.

I cannot get her for my life
to instruct her hand thus, before and after, which a knight will look for, before and after.
I have told her still, 'tis the waving of a woman does often move a man, and prevails strongly.
But sweet, ha you sent to Cambridge, (Has Tim word an't?)

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Had word just the day after when you sent him the silver spoon to eat his broth in the hall, amongst the gentlemen commoners.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O 'twas timely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: A letter from a gentleman in Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O one of Hobson's porters, thou art welcome.
I told thee Maud we should hear from Tim. Amantissimis charissimisque ambobus parentibus patri et matri.

sp.speaker: Maudl
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, I know not, ask not me, he's grown too verbal, this learning is a great witch.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Pray let me see it, I was wont to understand him.
Amantissimus charissimus, he has sent the carrier's man he says: ambobus parentibus, for a pair of boots: patri et matri, pay the porter, or it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Yes by my faith mistress, there's no true construction in that, I have taken a great deal of pains, and come from the bell sweating. Let me come to't, for I was a scholar forty years ago, 'tis thus I warrant you: matri, it makes no matter: ambobus parentibus, for a pair of boots: patri, pay the porter: amantissimis charissimis, he's the carrier's man, and his name is Sims, and there he says true, forsooth my name is Sims indeed, I have not forgotten all my learning. A money matter, I thought I should hit on't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Go thou art an old fox, there's a tester for thee.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: If I see your worship at goose fair, I have a dish of birds for you.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Why dost dwell at bow?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: All my life time sir I could ever say bo, to a goose. Farewell to your worship.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: A merry porter.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How can he choose but be so, coming with Cambridge letters from our son Tim?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's here, maximus diligo, faith I must to my learned counsel with this gear, 'twill ne'er be discerned else.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Go to my cousin then, at inns of court.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Fie they are all for French, they speak no Latin.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: The parson then will do it.

div.stage: Enter a gentleman with a chain.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay he disclaims it, calls Latin papistry, he will not deal with it. What is't you lack gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray weigh this chain.

div.stage: Enter sir Walter Whorehound, Welch gentlewoman, and Davy Dahanna.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now wench thou art welcome to the heart of the city of London.

sp.speaker: W. gent.
sp.p: Dugat a whee.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You can thank me in English if you list.

sp.speaker: W. gent.
sp.p: I can sir simply.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Twill serve to pass wench, 'twas strange that I should lie with thee so often, to leave thee without English, that were unnatural, I bring thee up to turn thee into gold wench, and make thy fortune shine like your bright trade, a goldsmith's shop sets out a city maid. Davy Dahanna, not a word.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Mum, mum sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here you must pass for a pure virgin.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Pure Welsh virgin, she lost her maidenhead in Brekenockeshire.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I hear you mumble Davy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I have teeth sir, I need not mumble yet this forty years.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The knave bites plaguely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your price sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A hundred pound sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: A hundred marks the utmost, 'tis not for me else.
What sir Walter Whorehound?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O death.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Why daughter.
Faith the baggage a bashful girl sir, these young things are shamefast, besides you have a presence sweet sir Walter, able to daunt a maid brought up i'the city,
A brave court spirit makes our virgin's quiver, and kiss with trembling thighs. Yet see she comes sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Why how now pretty mistress, now I have caught you. What can you injure so your time to stray thus from your faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Pish, stop your words good knight, 'twill make her blush else, which wound too high for the daughters of the freedom, honour, and faithful servant, they are compliments for the worthies of Whitehall, or Greenwich, e'en plain, sufficient, subsidy words serves us sir. And is this gentlewoman your worthy niece?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You may be bold with her on these terms, 'tis she sir, heir to some nineteen mountains.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Bless us all, you overwhelm me sir with love and riches.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: And all as high as Paul's.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Here's work i'faith.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How sayest thou Davy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Higher sir by far, you cannot see the top of 'em.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What man? Maudlin salute this gentlewoman, our daughter if things hit right.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: My knight with a brace of footmen, is come and brought up his ewe mutton, to find a ram at London, I must hasten it, or else pick a famine, her blood's mine, and that's the surest. Well knight, that choice spoy is only kept for me.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Turn not to me till thou mayst lawfully, it but whets my stomach, which is too sharp set already. Read that note carefully, keep me from suspicion still, nor know my zeal but in thy heart: read and send but thy liking in three words, I'll be at hand to take it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O turn sir, turn.
A poor plain boy, an university man, proceeds next lent to a bachelor of art, he will be called sir Yellowhammer then over all Cambridge, and that's half a knight.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Please you draw near, and taste the welcome of the city sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come good sir Walter, and your virtuous niece here.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis manners to take kindness.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Lead 'em in wife.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Your company sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I'll give't you instantly.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: How strangely busy is the devil and riches,
Poor soul kept in too hard, her mother's eye, is cruel towards her, being to him, 'twere a good mirth now to set him a work to make her wedding ring. I must about it.
Rather than the gain should fall to a stranger, 'twas honesty in me to enrich my father.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l:
The girl is wondrous peevish, I fear nothing, but that she's taken with some other love,
then all's quite dashed, that must be narrowly looked to, we cannot be too wary in our children. What is't you lack?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: O nothing now, all that I wish is present.
I would have a wedding ring made for a gentlewoman, with all speed that may be.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Of what weight sir?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Of some half ounce, stand fair and comely, with the spark of a diamond.
Sir 'twere pity to lose the least grace.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Pray let's see it, indeed sir 'tis a pure one.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: So is the mistress.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Have you the wideness of her finger sir?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Yes sure I think I have her measure about me, good faith 'tis down, I cannot show't you,
I must pull too many things out to be certain.
Let me see, long, and slender, and neatly jointed,
Just such another gentlewoman that's your daughter sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And therefore sir no gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: I protest I never saw two maids handed more alike
I'll ne'er seek farther, if you'll give me leave sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: If you dare venture by her finger sir.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Ay, and I'll bide all loss sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Say you so sir, let's see hither girl.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Shall I make bold with your finger gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: That fits her to a hair sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your posy now sir?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Mass that's true, posy i'faith e'en thus sir.
Love that's wise, blinds parents' eyes.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: How, how, if I may speak without offence sir,
I hold my life

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Go too, you'll pardon me?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Pardon you? I sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Will you i'faith?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Yes faith I will.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: You'll steal away some man's daughter, am I near you?

Do you turn aside? You gentlemen are mad wage, I
wonder things can be so warily carried, and parents blinded so, but they're served right that have two eyes, and were so dull a fight.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Thy doom take hold of thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Tomorrow noon shall show your ring well done.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Being so 'tis soon, thanks, and your leave sweet gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Sir you are welcome.
O were I made of wishes, I went with thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come now we'll see how the rules go within.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: That robs my joy, there I lose all I win.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Honesty wash my eyes, I have spied a wittol.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What Davy Dahanna, welcome from North Wales
I'faith, and is sir Walter come?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Now come to town sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Into the maid's sweet Davy, and give order his chamber be made ready instantly, my wife's as great as she can wallow Davy, and longs for nothing but pickled cucumbers, and his coming, and now she shall have't boy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: She's sure of them sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thy very sight will hold my wife in pleasure, till the knight come himself. Goin, in, in Davy.
The founders come to town, I am like a man finding a table furnished to his hand, as mine is still to me, prays for the founder, bless the right worshipful, the good founder's life.

I thank him, has maintained my house this ten years, not only keeps my wife, but 'a keeps me, and all my family, I am at his table, he gets me all my children, and pays the nurse, monthly, or weekly, puts me to nothing, rent, nor church duties, not so much as the scavenger, the happiest state that ever man was born to.
I walk out in a morning, come to breakfast,
Find excellent cheer, a good fire in winter,
Look in my coal-house about midsummer-eve,
That's full, five or six cauldron, new laid up,
Look in my back yard, I shall find a steeple
Made up with Kentish faggots, which o'erlooks
The water-house and the windmills, I say nothing
But smile, and pin the door, when she lies in,
As now she's even upon the point of grunting,
A lady lies not in like her, there's her imbossings,
Embroidering, spanglings, and I know not what,
As if she lay withal the gaudy shops
In Gressam's burse about her, than her restoratives,
Able to set up a young pothecary,
And richly stock, the foreman of a drug-shop.
Her sugar by whole loaves, her wines by roundlets.
I see these things, but like a happy man,
I pay for none at all, yet fools think's mine,
I have the name, and in his gold I shine.
And where some merchants would in soul kiss hell,
To buy a paradise for their wines, and die
Their conscience in the bloods of prodigal heirs,
To deck their night-piece, yet all this being done,
Eaten with jealousy to the inmost bone,
As what affliction nature more constrains,
Then feed the wife plump, for another's veins.
These torments stand I freed of, I am as clear
From jealousy of a wife, as from the charge.
O two miraculous blessings, 'tis the knight
Hath taken that labour, all out of my hands,
I may sit still and play, he's jealous for me,
Watches her steps, sets spies, I live at ease,
He has both the cost and torment, when the strings
Of his heart frets, I feed, laugh, or sing,
La dildo, dildo la dildo, la dildo dildo de dildo.

sp.p: What has he got a singing in his head now?
Now's out of work he falls to making dildoes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now sirs, sir Walters come.
Is our master come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Your master, what am I?
Do not you know sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray am not I your master?
O you are but our mistress's husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ergo knave, your master.
Negatur argumentum. Here comes sirWalter, now a stands bare as well as we, make the most of him he's but one peep above a servingman, and so much his horns make him.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How dost Jack?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Proud of your worship's health sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How does your wife?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: E'en after your own making sir,
She's a tumbler a faith, the nose and belly meets.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: They'll part in time again.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: At the good hour, they will and please your worship.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here sirrah, pull off my boots. Put on, but on Jack.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I thank your kind worship sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Slippers, heart you are sleepy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The game begins already.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Pish, put on Jack.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now I must do it, or he'll be as angry now, as if I had put it on at first bidding, 'tis but observing, 'tis but observing a man's humour once, and he may ha' him by the nose all his life.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: What entertainment has lain open here,
No strangers in my absence?

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Sure sir not any.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: His jealousy begins, am not I happy now
That can laugh inward whilst his marrow melts?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How do you satisfy me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Good sir be patient.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: For two months absence I'll be satisfied.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: No living creature entered.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Entered, come swear.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: You will not hear me out sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yes I'll hear't out sir.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: Sir he can tell himself.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Heart he can tell,
Do you think I'll trust him? As a usurer
With forfeited lordships. Him, o monstrous injury!
Believe him, can the devil speak ill of darkness?
What can you say sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of my soul and conscience sir, she's a wife as honest of her body to me, as any lords proud lady can be.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yet by your leave, I heard you were once offering to go to bed to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No I protest sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Heart if you do, you shall take all, I'll marry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O I beseech you sir,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: That wakes the slave, and keeps his flesh in awe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'll stop that gap
Where'er I find it open, I have poisoned
His hopes in marriage already,
Some old rich widows, and some landed virgins,
And I'll fall to work still before I'll lose him,
He's yet too sweet to part from.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.p: God-den father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha villain, peace.

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.p: God-den father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Peace bastard, should he hear 'em. 〈◊〉 are two foolish children, they do not know the gentleman that sits there.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O Wat, how dost Nick? Go to school,
Ply your books boys, ha?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Where's your legs whore sons? They should kneel indeed if they could say their prayers.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Let me see, stay,
How shall I dispose of these two brats now
When I am married, for they must not mingle
Amongst my children that I get in wedlock,
'Twill make foul work that, and raise many storms.
I'll bind what prentice to a goldsmith, my father yellowh.
As fit as can be. Nick with some vintner, good, goldsmith
And vintner, there will be wine in boles i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sweet knight
Welcome, I have all my longings now in town,
Now welcome the good hour.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How cheers my mistress?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Made lightsome, e'en by him that made me heavy.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: methinks she shows gallantly, like a moon at full sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: True, and if she bear a male child, there's the man in the moon sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis but the boy in the moon yet goodman calf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There was a man, the boy had never been there else.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It shall be yours sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No by my troth, I'll swear it's none of mine, let him that got it keep it, thus do I rid myself of fear, lie soft, sleep hard, drink wine, and eat good cheer.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Senior, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill be so tedious sir to live from you,
But that necessity must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I would it might not wife, the tediousness
Will be the most part mine, that understand
The blessings I have in thee, so to part
That drives the torment to a knowing heart,
But as thou say'st, we must give way to need
All live awhile asunder, our desires
Are both too fruitful for our barren fortunes.
How adverse runs the destiny of some creatures,
Some only can get riches and no children,
We only can get children and no riches,
Then 'tis the prudents part to check our wills,
And till our state rise, make our bloods lie still.
'Life every year a child, and some years two,
Besides, drinkings abroad, that's never reckoned,
This gear will not hold out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir for a time, I'll take the courtesy of my uncle's house
If you be pleased to like on't, till prosperity
Look with a friendly eye upon our states.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Honest wife I thank thee, I never knew
The perfect treasure thou broughtest with thee more
Than at this instant minute. A man's happy
When he's at poorest that has matched his soul
As rightly as his body. Had I married
A sensual fool now, as 'tis hard to scape it
'Mongst gentlewomen of our time, she would ha' hanged
About my neck, and never left her hold
Till she had kissed me into wanton businesses,
Which at the waking of my better judgement
I should have cursed most bitterly,
And laid a thicker vengeance on my act
Then misery of the birth, which were enough
If it were born to greatness, whereas mine
Is sure of beggary, though it were got in wine.
Fullness of joy showeth the goodness in thee,
Thou art a matchless wife, farewell my joy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I shall not want your sight?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I'll see thee often,
Talk in mirth, and play at kisses with thee,
Any thing wench but what may beget beggars,
There I give o'er the set, throw down the cards,
And dare not take them up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your will be mine sir.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: This does not only make her honesty perfect,
But her discretion, and approves her judgement.
Had her desire been wanton, they'd been blameless
In being lawful ever, but of all creatures
I hold that wife a most unmatched treasure,
That can unto her fortunes fix her pleasure,
And not unto her blood, this is like wedlock,
The feast of marriage is not lust but love,
And care of the estate, when I please blood,
Merely I sing, and suck out others, then
'Tis many a wiseman's fault, but of all men
I am the most unfortunate in that game
That ever pleased both genders, I never played yet
Under a bastard, the poor wenches curse me
To the pit where'er I come, they were never served so,
But used to have more words than one to a bargain,
I have such a fatal finger in such business
I must forth with't, chiefly for country wenches,
For every harvest I shall hinder hay-making,
sp.stage: Enter a wench with a child.
sp.l: I had no less than seven lay in last progress,
Within three weeks of one another's time.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: O Snaphance, have I found you.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: How Snaphance?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Do you see your workmanship,
Nay turn not from it, nor offer to escape, for if you do,
I'll cry it through the streets, and follow you.
Your name may well be called Tuchwood, a pox on you,
You do but touch and take, thou hast undone me,
I was a maid before, I can bring a certificate for it,
From both the churchwardens.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: I'll have the parsons hand too, or I'll not yield to't.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou shalt have more thou villain, nothing grieves me, but Ellen my poor cousin in Derbyshire, thou hast cracked her marriage quite, she'll have a bout with thee.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Faith when she will I'll have a bout with her.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: A law bout sir I mean.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: True, lawyers use such bouts as other men do,
And if that be all thy grief, I'll tender her a husband,
I keep of purpose two or three gulls in pickle
To eat such mutton with, and she shall choose one.
Do but in courtesy faith wench excuse me,
Of this half yard of flesh, in which I think it wants
A nail or two.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: No, thou shalt find villain
It hath right shape, and all the nails it should have.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Faith I am poor, do a charitable deed wench,
I am a younger brother, and have nothing.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Nothing, thou hast too much thou lying villain
Unless thou wert more thankful.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I have no dwelling,
I broke up house but this morning, pray thee pity me,
I am a good fellow, faith have been too kind
To people of your gender, if I have't
Without my belly, none of your sex shall want it,
That word has been of force to move a woman.
There's tricks enough to rid thy hand on't wench,
some rich-mans porch, tomorrow before day,
Or else anon i'the evening, twenty devises,
Here's all I have, i'faith, take purse and all,
And would I were rid of all the ware i'the shop so.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Where I find manly dealings I am pitiful,
This shall not trouble you.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: And I protest wench, the next I'll keep myself.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Soft, let it be got first.
This is the fifth, if e'er I venture more
Where I now go for a maid, may I ride for a whore.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: What shift she'll make now with this piece of flesh
In this strict time of Lent, I cannot imagine,
Flesh dare not peep abroad now, I have known
This city now above this seven years,
But I protest in better state of government,
I never knew it yet, nor ever heard of,
There has been more religious wholesome laws
In the half circle of a year erected
For common good, than memory ever knew of,
sp.stage: Enter sir Oliver Kix, and his lady.
sp.l: Setting apart corruption of promoters,
And other poisonous officers that infect
And with a venomous breath taint every goodness.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O that e'er I was begotten, or bred, or born.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Be content sweet wife.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: What's here to do now?
I hold my life she's in deep passion
For the imprisonment of veal and mutton
Now kept in garrets, weeps for some calf's head now,
Methinks her husband's head might serve with bacon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hist.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Patience sweet wife.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Brother I have sought you strangely.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Why what's the business?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: With all speed thou canst procure a licence for me.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: How, a licence?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Cuds-foot she's lost else, I shall miss her ever.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Nay sure thou shalt not miss so fair a mark ▪
For thirteen shillings four pence.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Thanks by hundreds.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay pray thee cease, I'll be at more cost yet,
Thou knowest we are rich enough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: All but in blessings,
And there the beggar goes beyond us. O, o, o,
To be seven years a wife and not a child, o not a child.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Sweet wife have patience.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can any woman have a greater cut?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I know 'tis great, but what of that wife?
I cannot do with all, there's things making
By thine own doctor's advice at pothecaries,
I spare for nothing wife, no if the price
Were forty marks a spoonful,
I'd give a thousand pound to purchase fruitfulness,
'Tis but bating so many good works
In the erecting of Bridewels and spittle-houses,
And so fetch it up again, for having none
I mean to make good deeds my children.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Give me but those good deeds, and I'll find children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang thee, thou hast had too many.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou'dst brevity.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O horrible, dar'st thou call me brevity?
Darest thou be so short with me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou deservest worse.
Think but upon the goodly lands and livings
That's kept back through want on't.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Talk not on't pray thee,
thou'lt make me play the woman, and weep too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis our dry barrenness puffs up sir Walter,
None gets by your not-getting, but that knight,
He's made by th' means, and fats his fortunes, shortly
In a great dowry with a goldsmith's daughter.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: They may be all deceived,
Be but you patient wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have suffered a long time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Suffer thy heart out, a pox suffer thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay thee, thou desertless slave.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Come, come, I ha' done,
You'll to the gossipping of Mr. Allwit's child?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, to my much joy,
Every one gets before me, there's my sister
Was married but at Barthomew-eve last,
And she can have two children at a birth,
Oh one of them, one of them would ha' served my turn.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Sorrow consume thee, thou art still crossing me,
And knowest my nature.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O mistress, weeping or railing,
That's our house harmony.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What say'st Jugg?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The sweetest news.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What is't wench?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Throw down your doctor's drugs,
They're all but heretics, I bring certain remedy
That has been taught, and proved, and never failed.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: O that, that, that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: There's a gentleman,
I haply have his name too, that has got
Nine children by one water that he useth,
It never misses , they come so fast upon him,
He was fain to give it over.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: His name sweet Jugg?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: One Mr. Tuchwood, a fine gentleman,
But run behindhand much with getting children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Why sir, he'll undertake,
Using that water, within fifteen year,
For all your wealth, to make you a poor man,
You shall so swarm with children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'll venture that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That shall you husband.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But I must tell you first, he's very dear.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: No matter, what serves wealth for?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: True sweet husband,
There's land to come, put case his water stands me
In some five hundred pound a pint,
'Twill fetch a thousand, and a Kersten soul.
I'll about it.
And that's worth all sweet husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'll go bid gossips presently myself,
That's all the work I'll do, nor need I stir,
But that it is my pleasure to walk forth
And air myself a little, I am tied to nothing
In this business, what I do is merely recreation,
Not constraint.
Here's running to and fro, nurse upon nurse,
Three chare women, besides maids and neighbour's children.
Fie, what a trouble have I rid my hands on,
It makes me sweat to think on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How now Jack?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am going to bid gossips for your worship's child sir,
A goodly girl i'faith, give you joy on her,
She looks as if she had two thousand pound to her portion
And run away with a tailor, a fine plump black eyed slut,
Under correction sir,
I take delight to see her: nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Do you call sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I call not you, I call the wet nurse hither,
Give me the wet nurse, I 'tis thou,
Come hither, come hither,
Let's see her once again; I cannot choose
But buss her thrice an hour.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You may be proud on't sir,
'Tis the best piece of work that e'er you did.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thinkest thou so nurse, what sayest to Wat and Nick?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They're pretty children both, but here's a wench
Will be a knocker.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Pup say'st thou me so, pup little countess,
Faith sir I thank your worship for this girl,
Ten thousand times, and upward.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am glad I have her for you sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here take her in nurse, wipe her, and give her spoon-meat.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Wipe your mouth sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And now about these gossips.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Get but two, I'll stand for one myself.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To your own child sir?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The better policy, it prevents suspicion,
'Tis good to play with rumor at all weapons.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Troth I commend your care sir, 'tis a thing
That I should never have thought on.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The more slave,
When man turns base, out goes his souls pure flame,
The fat of ease o'erthrows the eyes of shame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am studying who to get for godmother
Suitable to your worship, now I ha' thought on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I'll ease you of that care, and please myself in't
My love the goldsmith's daughter, if I send,
Her father will command her, Davy Dahumma.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'll fit your worship then with a male partner.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A kind proper gentleman, brother to Mr. Tuchwood.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I know Tuchwood, has he a brother living?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A neat bachelor.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Now we know him, we'll make shift with him
Dispatch the time draws near, come hither Davy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In troth I pity him, he never stands still,
Poor knight what pains he takes, sends this way one,
That way another, has not an hour's leisure,
I would not have thy toil, for all thy pleasure,
Ha, how now, what are these that stand so close
At the street-corner, pricking up their ears,
And snuffing up their noses, like rich-men's dogs
When the first course goes in? By the mass promoters,
'Tis so I hold my life, and planted there
To arrest the dead corpse of poor calves and sheep,
Like ravenous creditors, that will not suffer
The bodies of their poor departed debtors
To go to'th' grave, but e'en in death to vex
And stay the corpse, with bills of Middlesex,
This lent will fat the whoresons up with sweetbreads,
And lard their whores with lamb-stones, what their golls
Can clutch, goes presently to their molls and dols,
The bawds will be so fat with what they earn,
their chins will hang like udders, by Easter-eve,
And being stroked, will give the milk of witches,
How did the mongrels hear my wife lies in?
Well, I may baffle 'em gallantly, by your favour gentlemen
I am a stranger both unto the city,
And to her carnal strictness.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Good, your will sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray tell me where one dwells that kills this lent.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: How kills? Come hither Dick,
A bird, a bird.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What is't that you would have?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Faith any flesh,
But I long especially for veal and greensauce.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Green-goose, you shall be sauced.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I have half a scornful stomach, no fish will be admitted.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Not this lent sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lent, what cares Colon here for Lent?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You say well sir,
Good reason that the colon of a gentleman
As you were lately pleased to term your worship sir,
Should be fulfilled with answerable food,
To sharpen blood, delight health, and tickle nature,
Were you directed hither to this street sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That I was, I marry.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: And the butcher belike
Should kill, and sell close in some upper room?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Some apple-loft as I take it, or a coal-house,
I know not which i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Either will serve,
This butcher shall kiss Newgate, less he turn up the
Bottom of the pocket of his apron,
You go to seek him?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Where you shall not find him,
I'll buy, walk by your noses with my flesh,
Sheep-biting mongrels, hand-basket freebooters,
My wife lies in, a foutra for promoters.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: That shall not serve your turn, what a rogue's this, how cunningly he came over us?

div.stage: Enter a man with meat in a basket.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Husht, stand close.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I have 'scaped well thus far, they say the knaves are wondrous hot and busy.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By your leave sir,
We must see what you have under your cloak there.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Have? I have nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: No, do you tell us that, what makes this lump stick out then, we must see sir.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: What will you see sir, a pair of sheets, and two of my wife's foul smocks, going to the washers?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: O we love that sight well, you cannot please us better: what do you gull us, call you these shirts and smocks?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: Now a pox choke you,
You have cozened me and five of my wife's kindred
Of a good dinner, we must make it up now
With herrings and milk-pottage.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: 'Tis all veal.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: All veal, pox the worse luck, I promised faithfully to send this morning a fat quarter of lamb, to a kind gentlewoman in Turnbull street that longs, and how I'm crossed.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Let's share this, and see what hap comes next then.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Agreed, stand close again, another booty,
What's he?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Sir, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Meaning me sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Good Mr. Oliver, cry thee mercy, i'faith.
What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A rack of mutton sir, and half a lamb,
You know my mistress's diet.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Go, go, we see thee not, away, keep close,
Heart let him pass, thou'lt never have the wit
To know our benefactors.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I have forgotten him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: 'Tis m. Beggerland's man the wealthy merchant
That is in fee with us.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Now I have a feeling of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You know he purchased the whole lent together
Gave us ten groats a piece on Ash-wednesday.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: True, true.

div.stage: Enter a wench with a basket, and a child in it under a loin of mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A wench.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then stand close indeed.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Women had need of wit, if they'll shift here,
And she that hath wit, may shift anywhere.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Look, look, poor fool,
She has left the rump uncovered too,
More to betray her, this is like a murderer,
That will outface the deed with a bloody band.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What time of the year is't sister?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O sweet gentlemen, I am a poor servant,
Let me go.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: You shall wench, but this must stay with us.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O you undo me sir,
'Tis for a wealthy gentlewoman that takes physic sir,
The doctor does allow my mistress mutton,
Oh as you tender the dear life of a gentlewoman,
I'll bring my master to you, he shall show you
A true authority from the higher powers,
And I'll run every foot.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Well, leave your basket then,
and run and spare not.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Will you swear then to me,
To keep it till I come.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Now by this light I will.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What say you gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: What a strange wench 'tis?
Would we might perish else.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Nay then I run sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: And never return I hope.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: A politic baggage,
She makes us swear to keep it,
I prithee look what market she hath made.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Imprimis sir, a good fat loin of mutton,
What comes next under this cloth?
Now for a quarter of lamb.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Not for a shoulder of mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why done sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By the mass I feel I have lost,
'Tis of more weight i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Some loin of veal?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: No faith, here's a lamb's head,
I feel that plainly, why yet win my wager.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: 'Swounds what's here?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: A child.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A pox of all dissembling cunning whores.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Here's an unlucky breakfast.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: What shall's do?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: The quean made us swear to keep it too.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: We might leave it else.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Villainous strange,
'Life had she none to gull, but poor promoters,
That watch hard for a living.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Half our gettings must run in sugar-soap,
And nurse's wages now, besides many a pound of soap,
And tallow, we have need to get loins of mutton still,
to save suet to change for candles.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Nothing mads me, but this was a lamb's head with you, you felt it, she has made calf's heads of us.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Prithee no more on't,
There's time to get it up, it is not come
To mid-lent Sunday yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I am so angry, I'll watch no more today.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Faith nor I neither.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then I'll make a motion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Well, what is't?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Let's e'en go to the chequer at queen-hive and roast the loin of mutton, till young flood, then send the child to Branford.

div.stage: Enter Allwit in one of sir walters suits, and Davy trussing him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis a busy day at our house Davy.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.p: Always the kursning day sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Truss, truss me Davy.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.p: No matter and you were hanged sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How does this suit fit me Davy?

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.p: Excellent neatly, my master's things were ever fit for you sir, e'en to a hair you know.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thou hast hit it right Davy,
We ever jumped in one, this ten years Davy,
sp.stage: Enter a servant with a box.
sp.l: So well said, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Your comfit-maker's man sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O sweet youth, into the nurse quick,
Quick, 'tis time i'faith,
Your mistress will be here?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: She was setting forth sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here comes our gossips now, oh I shall have such kissing work today, sweet mistress Underman welcome i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.l: Give you joy of your fine girl sir,
Grant that her education may be pure,
And become one of the faithful.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thanks to your sisterly wishes Mr. Underman.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: Are any of the brothers' wives yet come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There are some wives within, and some at home.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Verily thanks sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Verily you are an ass forsooth,
I must sit all these times, or there's no music,
Here comes a friendly and familiar payer,
Now I like these wenches well.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.p: How dost sirrah?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Faith well I thank you neighbour, and how dost thou?

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Want nothing, but such getting sir as thine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: My gettings wench, they are poor.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.l: Fie that thou'lt say so,
Thou'st as fine children as a man can get.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.l: I as a man can get,
And that's my master.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: They are pretty foolish things,
Put to making in minutes,
I never stand long about 'em,
Will you walk in wenches?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: The hapiest meeting that our souls could wish for
Here's the ring ready, I am beholding unto your father's haste, has kept his hour.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: He never kept it better.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Back, be silent.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Mistress and partner, I will put you both into one cup.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.l: Into one cup, most proper,
A fitting compliment for a goldsmith's daughter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Yes sir, that's he must be your worship's partner
In this day's business, Mr. Tuchwood's brother.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I embrace your acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: It vows your service sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It's near high time, come Mr. Allwit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ready sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Wil't please you walk?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Sir I obey your time.

div.stage: Enter midwife with the child, and the gossips to the kursning.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.p: Good mrs. Yellowhammer.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In faith I will not.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.p: Indeed it shall be yours

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I have sworn I saith.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.p: I'll stand still then.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: So will you let the child go without company
And make me forsworn.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.p: You are such another creature.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Before me, I pray come down a little.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Not a whit, I hope I know my place.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Your place, great wonder sure, are you any better than a comfit-maker's wife.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: And that's as good at all times as a apothecary's.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Ye lie, yet I forbear you too.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Come sweet sister, we go in unity, and show the fruits of peace like children of the spirit.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I love lowliness.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.l: True, so say I, though they strive more,
There comes as proud behind, as goes before.

sp.speaker: 5 gossip
sp.p: Every inch i'faith.

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood junior, and a parson.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: O sir, if ever you felt the force of love, pity it in me.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: Yes, though I never was married sir,
I have felt the force of love from good men's daughters,
And some that will be maids yet three years hence.
Have you got a licence?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Here 'tis ready sir.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: The ring and all things perfect, she'll steal hither.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: She shall be welcome sir, I'll not be long
A clapping you together.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: O here she's come sir.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: My honest brother.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Quick, make haste sirs.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: You must dispatch with all the speed you can,
For I shall be missed straight, I made hard shift
for this small time I have.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: Then I'll not linger,
Place that ring upon her finger,
This the finger plays the part,
Whose master vein shoots from the heart,
Now join hands.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Which I will sever,
And so never again meet never.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Hard fate.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am struck with wonder.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Was this the politic fetch, thou mystical baggage
Thou disobedient strumpet,
And were so wise to send for her to such an end,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now I disclaim the end, you'll make me mad.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And what are you sir?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: And you cannot see with those two glasses, put on a pair more.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I dreamt of anger still, here take your ring sir,
Ha this, life 'tis the same, abominable,
Did not I sell this ring?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: I think you did, you received money for't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Heart, hark you knight,
Here's no inconscionable villainy,
Set me a work to make the wedding ring,
And come with an intent to steal my daughter,
Did ever runaway match it?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: this your brother sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: He can tell that as well as I.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: The very poesy mocks me to my face,
Love that's wise, blinds parents' eyes,
I thank your wisdom sir for blinding of us,
We have good hope to recover our sight shortly,
In the mean time I will lock up this baggage,
as carefully as my gold, she shall see as little sun
If a close room or so can keep her from the light on't.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O sweet father, for love's sake pity me.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Farewell sir, all content bless thee,
And take this for comfort,
Though violence keep me, thou canst lose me never,
I am ever thine although we part for ever.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I we shall part you minx.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Your acquaintance sir, came very lately,
Yet it came too soon,
I must hereafter know you for no friend,
But one that I must shun like pestilence,
Or the disease of lust.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Like enough sir, you ha' ta'en me at the worst time for words that e'er ye picked out, faith do not wrong me sir.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Look after him and spare not, there he walks
That never yet received baffling, you're blessed
More than e'er I knew, go take your rest.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I pardon you, you are both losers'.

div.stage: A bed thrust out upon the stage, Allwit's wife in it, enter all the gossips.

sp.speaker: 1 gossip
sp.l: How is't woman, we have brought you home
A Kursen soul.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, I thank your pains.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: And verily well kirsened, i'the right way,
Without idolatry or superstition,
After the pure manner of Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sit down good neighbours, nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: At hand forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Look they have all low stools

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: They have forsooth.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.l: Bring the child hither nurse, how say you now
Gossip, is't not a chopping girl, so like the father?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.l: As if it had been spit out of his mouth,
By'd, nosed, and browed as like a girl can be,
Only indeed it has the mother's mouth.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: The mother's mouth up and down, up and down.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: 'Tis a large child, she's but a little woman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: No believe me, a very spiny creature, but all heart,
Well metteld, like the faithful to endure
Her tribulation here, and raise up seed.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: She had a sore labour on't I warrant you, you can tell neighbour.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.l: Oh she had great speed,
We were afraid once,
But she made us all have joyful hearts again,
'Tis a good soul i'faith,
The midwife found her a most cheerful daughter.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: 'Tis the spirit, the sisters are all like her,

div.stage: Enter sir Walter with two spoons and plate and Allwit.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Oh here comes the chief gossip neighbours.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The fatness of your wishes to you all ladies.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.l: Oh dear sweet gentleman, what fine words he has
The fatness of our wishes.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Calls us all ladies.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: I promise you a fine gentleman, and a courteous.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: methinks her husband shows like a clown to him.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: I would not care what clown my husband were too, so I had such fine children.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: She's all fine children gossip.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Ay, and see how fast they come.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Children are blessings, if they be got with zeal,
By the brothers, as I have five at home.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The worst is past, I hope now gossip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: So I hope to good sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why then so hope I too for company,
I have nothing to do else.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: A poor remembrance lady,
To the love of the babe, I pray accept of it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O you are at too much charge sir.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Look, look, what has he given her, what is't gossip?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Now by my faith a fair high standing cup, and two great postle spoons, one of them gilt.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Sure that was Judas then with the red beard.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I would not feed my daughter with that spoon for all the world, for fear of colouring her heir, red hair the brothers like not, it consumes them much, 'tis not the sister's colour.

div.stage: Enter nurse with comfits and wine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Well said nurse,
About, about with them amongst the gossips,
Now out comes all the tasseld handkerchiefs,
They are spread abroad between their knees already,
Now in goes the long fingers that are washed
Some thrice a day in urine, my wife uses it,
Now we shall have such pocketing,
See how they lurch at the lower end.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Come hither nurse.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Again, she has taken twice already.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I had forgotten a sister's child that's sick.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
A pox it seems your purity loves sweet things well that puts in thrice together, had this been all my cost now I had been beggared, these women have no consciences at sweet meats, where'er they come, see and they have not could out all the long plumbs too, they have left nothing here but short riggle-tayle-comfits, not worth mouthing, no mar'le I heard a citizen complain once, that his wife's belly only broke his back: mine had been all in fitters seven years since, but for this worthy knight, that with a
prop upholds my wife and me, and all my estate buried in Bucklersbury.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Here mrs. Yellowhammer, and neighbours,
To you all that have taken pains with me,
All the good wives at once.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I'll answer for them,
They wish all health and strength,
And that you may courageously go forward,
To perform the like and many such,
Like a true sister with motherly bearing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now the cups troll about to wet the gossips whistles
It pours down i'faith, they never think of payment.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Fill again nurse.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now bless thee, two at once, I'll stay no longer,
It would kill me and if I paid for't,
Will it please you to walk down and leave the women.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: With all my heart Jack.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Troth I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Sit you all merry ladies.

sp.speaker: All gossip
sp.p: Thank your worship sir.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Thank your worship sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A pox twice tipple ye, you are last and lowest.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Bring hither that same cup-nurse, I would fain drive away this hup Antichristian grief.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.l: See gossip and she lies not in like a countess,
Would I had such a husband for my daughter.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: Is not she towards marriage?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Oh no sweet gossip.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: Why she's nineteen?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.l: I that she was last Lammas,
But she has a fault gossip, a secret fault.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: A fault, what is't?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: I'll tell you when I have drunk.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: Wine can do that I see, that friendship cannot.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: And now I'll tell you gossip, she's too free.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: To free?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Oh ay, she cannot lie dry in her bed.

sp.speaker: 4 gossip
sp.p: What, and nineteen?

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you gossip.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Speak with me nurse, who is't?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: A gentleman from Cambridge,
I think it be your soon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: 'Tis my soon Tim i'faith,
Prithee call him up among the women,
'Twill embolden him well,
For he wants nothing but audacity
'Wouldwould the Welsh gentlewoman at home were here now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is your son come forsooth?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes from the university forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis great joy on ye.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: There's a great marriage towards for him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A marriage?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Yes sure, a huge heir in Wales,
At least to nineteen mountains,
Besides her goods and cattle.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O, I'm betrayed.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: What gone again, run after him good nurse,
He's so bashful, that's the spoil of youth,
In the university they're kept still to men,
And never trained up to women's company.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis a great spoil of youth indeed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Your mother will have it so.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why son, why Tim,
What must I rise and fetch you? For shame son.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mother you do entreat like a fresh woman,
'Tis against the laws of the university,
For any that has answered under bachelor
To thrust 'mongst married wives.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Come we'll excuse you here.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Call up my tutor mother, and I care not.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What is your tutor come, have you brought him up?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I ha' not brought him up, he stands at door,
Negatur, there's logic to begin with you mother.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Run call the gentleman nurse, he's my son's tutor
Here eat some plumbs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come I from Cambridge, and offer me six plumbs?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why how now Tim,
Will not your old tricks yet be left?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Served like a child,
When I have answered under Batcheler?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: You'll never lin till I make your tutor whip you, you know how I served you once at the free school in Paul's churchyard?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O monstrous absurdity,
Never was the like in Cambridge since my time,
'Life whip a bachelor, you'd be laughed at soundly,
Let not my tutor hear you,
'Twould be a jest through the whole university,
No more words mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Is this your tutor Tim?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Yes surely lady, I am the man that brought him in league with logic, and read the dunces to him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That did he mother, but now I have 'em all in my own pate, and can as well read 'em to others.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: That can he mistress, for they flow naturally from him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'm the more beholding to your pains sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: No● ideo sa●●.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: True, he was an idiot indeed,
When he went out of London, but now he's well mended ▪
Did you receive the two goose-pies I sent you?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: And eat them heartily, thanks to your worship.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: 'Tis my son Tim, I pray bid him welcome gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tim, hark you Timotheus' mother, Timothius.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How, shall I deny your name? Timothius quoth he? Faith there's a name, 'tis my son Tim forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You're welcome Mr. Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O this is horrible, she wets as she kisses,
Your handkercher sweet tutor, to wipe them off, as fast as they come on.

sp.speaker: 2 gossip
sp.p: Welcome from Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: This is intolerable, this woman has a villainous sweet breath, did she not stink of comfits, help me sweet tutor, or I shall rub my lips off.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I'll go kiss the lower end the whilst.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Perhaps that's the sweeter, and we shall dispatch the sooner.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Let me come next, welcome from the wellspring of discipline, that waters all the brothers.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hoist I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: 3 gossip
sp.p: Oh bless the woman, Mr. Underman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: 'Tis but the common affliction of the faithful,
We must embrace our falls.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I'm glad I 'scaped it, it was some rotten kiss sure,
It dropped down before it came at me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here's a noise, not parted yet?
Hyda, a looking-glass, they have drunk so hard in plate,
That some of them had need of other vessels,
Yonder's the bravest show.

sp.speaker: All gossip
sp.p: Where? Where sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come along presently by the pissing-conduit,
With two brave drums and a standard-bearer.

sp.speaker: All gossip
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come tutor.

sp.speaker: All gossip
sp.p: Farewell sweet gossip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I thank you all for your pains.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Feed and grow strong.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: You had more need to sleep then eat,
Go take a nap with some of the brothers, go,
And rise up a well edified, boldified sister,
Oh here's a day of toil well passed o'er,
Able to make a citizen hare mad,
How hot they have made the room with their thick bums,
Dost not feel it Davy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Monstrous strong sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's here under the stools?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nothing but wet sir, some wine spilt here belike.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Is't no worse think'st thou?
Fair needle work stools, cost nothing with them Davy

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nor you neither i'faith.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Look how they have laid them,
E'en as they lie themselves, with their heels up,
How they have shufflled up the rushes too Davy
With their short figging little shittle-corke-heels,
These women can let nothing stand as they find it,
But what's the secret thou'st about to tell me
My honest Davy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: If you should disclose it sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Life rip my belly up to the throat than Davy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: My master's upon marriage.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Marriage Davy, send me to hanging rather.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I have stung him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: When, where, what is she Davy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: E'en the same was gossip, and gave the spoon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I have no time to stay, nor scarce can speak,
I'll stop those wheels, or all the work will break.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I knew 'twould prick, thus do I fashion still
All mine own ends by him and his rank toil,
'Tis my desire to keep him still from marriage,
being his poor nearest kinsman, I may fare
The better at his death, there my hopes build
Since my lady Kixe is dry, and hath no child.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: You're in the happiest way to enrich yourself,
And pleasure me brother, as man's feet can tread in,
For though she be locked up, her vow is fixed only to me;
Then time shall never grieve me, for by that vow,
E'en absent enjoy her, assuredly confirmed that none
Else shall, which will make tedious years seem gameful
To me, in the mean space lose you no time sweet brother,
You have the means to strike at this knights fortunes,
And lay him level with his bankrupt merit,
Get but his wife with child, perch at tree top,
And shake the golden fruit into her lap,
About it before she weep herself to a dry ground,
And whine out all her goodness.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Prithee cease, I find a too much aptness in my blood
For such a business without provocation,
You might well spared this banquet of oringoes,
Hartechokes, potatoes, and your buttered crab,
They were fitter kept for your own wedding dinner.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Nay and you'll follow my suit, and save my purse too
Fortune dotes on me, he's in happy case
Finds such an honest friend i'the common place.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Life what makes thee so merry? thou hast no cause
That I could hear of lately since thy crosses,
Unless there be news come, with new additions.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Why there thou hast it right,
I look for her this evening brother.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: How's that, look for her?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: I will deliver you of the wonder straight brother,
By the firm secrecy, and kind assistance
Of a good wench i'the house, who made of pity,
Weighing the case her own, she's led through gutters,
strange hidden ways, which none but love could find,
Or ha' the heart to venture, I expect her
Where you would little think.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: I care not where, so she be safe, and yours.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Hope tells me so,
But from your love and time my peace must grow.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: You know the worst then brother, now to my Kix
The barren he and she, they're i'the next room,
But to say which of their two humours hold them
Now at this instant, I cannot say truly.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou liest barrenness.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: O is't that time of day, give you joy of your tongue
There's nothing else good in you, this their life
The whole day from eyes open to eyes shut,
Kissing or scolding, and then must be made friends,
Then rail the second part of the first fit out,
And then be pleased again, no man knows which way,
Fall out like giants, and fall in like children,
Their fruit can witness as much.

div.stage: Enter sir Oliver Kix, and his lady.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis thy fault.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mine, drought and coldness?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thine, 'tis thou art barren.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I barren, o life that I durst but speak now,
In mine own justice, in mine own right, I barren,
'Twas otherways with me when I was at court,
I was never called so till I was married.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'll be divorced.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be hanged, I need not wish it,
That will come too soon to thee:
I may say, marriage and hanging goes by destiny,
For all the goodness I can find in't yet.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'll give up house, and keep some fruitful whore,
Like an old bachelor in a tradesman's chamber,
She and her children shall have all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where be they?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Pray cease,
When there are friendlier courses took for you,
To get and multiply within your house,
At your own proper costs in spite of censure,
Methinks an honest peace might be established.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What with her? Never.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Sweet sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: You work all in vain.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then he doth all like thee.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Let me entreat sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Singleness confound her,
I took her with one smock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But indeed you came not so single,
When you came from shipboard.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Heart she bit sore there,
Prithee make's friends.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Is't come to that, the peal begins to cease.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'll sell all at an outcry.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Do thy worst slave,
Good sweet sir bring us into love again.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Some would think this impossible to compass,
Pray let this storm fly over.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good sir pardon me, I'm master of this house,
Which I'll sell presently, I'll clap up bills this evening.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Lady friends come?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: If e'er ye loved woman, talk not on't sir, what friends with him? good faith do you think I'm mad with one that's scarce the hinder quarter of a man?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou art nothing of a woman.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Would I were less than nothing.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay prithee what dost mean?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I cannot please you.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'faith thou art a good soul, he lies that says it,
Buss, buss, pretty rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You care not for me.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Can any man tell now which way they came in?
By this light I'll be hanged then.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Is the drink come?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Here's a little vial of almond-milk
That stood me in some three pence.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I hope to see thee wench within these few years,
Circled with children, pranking up a girl,
And putting jewels in their little ears,
Fine sport I saith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I had you been ought husband,
It had been done ere this time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol
sp.l: Had I been ought, hang thee, hadst thou been ought,
But a cross thing I ever found thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou art a grub to say so.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: A pox on thee.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: By this light they are out again at the same door,
And no man can tell which way,
Come here's your drink sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I will not take it now sir,
And I were sure to get three boys ere midnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why there thou show'st now of what breed thou comest
To hinder generation, oh thou villain,
That knows how crookedly the world goes with us,
For want of heirs, yet put by all good fortune.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang strumpet, I will take it now in spite.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Then you must ride upon't five hours.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I mean so, within there?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Saddle the white mare,
I'll take a whore along, and ride to Ware.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ride to the devil.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'll plague you every way,
Look ye, do you see, 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A pox go with it.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I curse and spare not now.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Stir up and down sir, you must not stand.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay I'm not given to standing.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: So much the better sir for the —

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I never could stand long in one place yet,
I learned it of my father, ever figient,
How if I crossed this sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: O passing good sir, and would show well a horseback: when you come to your inn, if you leapt over a jointstool or two, 'twere not amiss although you broke your neck sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What say you to a table thus high sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Nothing better sir, if it be furnished with good victuals. You remember how the bargain runs about this business?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Or else I had a bad head: you must receive sir four hundred pounds of me at four several payments:
One hundred pound now in hand.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Right, that I have sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Another hundred when my wives is quick: the third when she's brought a-bed : and the last hundred when the child cries, for if it should be still born, it doth no good sir.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: All this is even still, a little faster sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not a whit sir,
I'm in an excellent pace for any physic,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Your white mares ready.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I shall up presently: one kiss, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou shalt have two love.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Expect me about three.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: With all my heart sweet.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: By this light they have forgotten their anger since,
And are as far in again as e'er they were,
Which way the devil came they, heart I saw 'em not,
Their ways are beyond finding out. Come sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How must I take mine sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Clean contrary, yours must be taken lying.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A bed sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: A bed, or where you will for your own ease,
Your coach will serve.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The physic must needs please.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Negatur argumentum tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Probo tibi pupil, stultus non est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faller is sane.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Quaso u● taceas, probo tibi.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Quomodo probae dominae.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Stultus non habet rationem, ergo non est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sic argumentaris dominae, stultus non habet rationem, ergo non est animal rationale, negatur argumentum again tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Argumentum itterum probo tibi dominae, qui non participate de ratione nullo modo potest vocari rationalibus, but stultus non participate de ratione, ergo stultus nullo modo potest dicere rationalis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Participate.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Sic disputus, qui participate quomodo participate.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ut homo, probabo tibi in silagismo.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Hunc proba.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sic probo dominae, stultus est homo sicut tu et ego sum, homo est animal rationele, sicut stultus est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Here's nothing but disputing all the day long with 'em.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Sic disputus, stultus est homo sicut tu et ego sum homo est animal rationale, sicut stultus est animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Your reasons are both good whate'er they be
Pray give them o'er, faith you'll tire yourselves,
What's the matter between you?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nothing but reasoning about a fool mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: About a fool son, alas what need you trouble your heads about that, none of us all but knows what a fool is.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why what's a fool mother?
I come to you now.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why one that's married before he has wit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty i'faith, and well guest of a woman never brought up at the university: but bring forth what fool you will mother, I'll prove him to be as reasonable a creature, as myself or my tutor here.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Fie 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Nay he shall do't forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis the easiest thing to prove a fool by logic,
By logic I'll prove any thing.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What thou wilt not?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'll prove a whore to be an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay by my faith, she must prove that herself, or logic will never do't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Twill do't I tell you.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Some in this street would give a thousand pounds that you could prove their wives so.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith I can, and all their daughters too, though they had three bastards. When comes your tailor hither?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why what of him?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By logic I'll prove him to be a man,
Let him come when he will.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: How hard at first was learning to him? Truly
Sir I thought he would never a taken the Latin tongue.
How many accidences do you think he wore out ere he came to his grammar?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Some three or four.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Believe me sir some four and thirty.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pish I made haberdins of 'em in church porches

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: He was eight years in his grammar, and stuck horribly at a foolish place there called ass in presenti.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pox I have it here now.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: He so shamed me once before an honest gentleman that knew me when I was a maid

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: These women must have all out.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Quidest gramatica? Says the gentleman to him (I shall remember by a sweet sweet token) but nothing could he answer.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: How now pupil, ha, quid est gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Grammatica? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay do not laugh son, but let me hear you say it now: there was one word went so prettily off the gentleman's tongue, I shall remember it the longest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Come, quid est gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Are you not ashamed tutor, gramatica? Why recte scribendi atque loquendi ars, ser-reverence of my mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: That was it i'faith: why now son I see you are a deep scholar: and Mr. tutor a word I pray, let us withdraw a little into my husband's chamber, I'll send in the North-wales gentlewoman to him, she looks for wooing: I'll put together both, and lock the door.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I give great approbation to your conclusion.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I mar'le what this gentlewoman should be,
That I should have in marriage, she's a stranger to me:
I wonder what my parents mean i'faith,
To match me with a stranger so:
a maid that's neither kiss nor kin to me:
Life do they think I have no more care of my body,
Then to lie with one that I never knew,
A mere stranger,
One that never went to school with me neither,
Nor ever playfellows together,
They're mightily o'erseen in't methinks ,
They say she has mountains to her marriage,
She's full of cattle, some two thousand runts,
Now what the meaning of these runts should be,
My tutor cannot tell me,
I have looked in riders dictionary for the letter r,
And there I can hear no tidings of these runts neither,
Unless they should be Rumford hogs,
I know them not,
And here she comes,
If I know what to say to her now
In the way of marriage, I'm no graduate,
Methinks i'faith 'tis boldly done of her
To come into my chamber being but a stranger,
She shall not say I'm so proud yet, but I'll speak to her,
Marry as I will order it,
She shall take no hold of my words I'll warrant her,
She looks and makes a curtsy,
Salve tu quoque pvella puleherima,
Quid vis nescio nec sane curo,
Tully's own phrase to a heart.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: I know not what he means,
A suitor quoth 'a?
I hold my life he understands no English.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ferter me hercule tu virgo,
Wallia ut opibus abundis maximis.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: What's this fertur and abundundis?
He mocks me sure, and calls me a bundle of farts.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I have no Latin word now for their runts, I'll make some shift or other: itterum dico opibus abundat maximis montibus et fontibus et ut ita dicam rontibus, attamen vero homauculus ego sum natura simule arte bachalarius lecto profecto non parata.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: This is most strange, may be he can speak Welsh,
Auedera whee comrage, der due cog foginis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Cog foggin, I scorn to cog with her, I'll tell her so too in a word near her own language: ego non cogo.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.p: Rhegosin a whiggin harle ron corid ambre.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By my faith she's a good scholar, I see that already
She has the tongue's plain, I hold my life she has travelled,
What will folks say? There goes the learned couple,
Faith if the truth were known, she hath proceeded.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How now, how speeds your business?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'm glad my mother's come to part us.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: How do you agree forsooth?

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.p: As well as e'er we did before we met.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: You put me to a man I understand not,
Your son's no English man methinks .

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: No English man, bless my boy,
And born i'the heart of London?

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: I ha' been long enough in the chamber with him,
And I find neither Welsh nor English in him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
