sp.p: Why Tim, how have you used the gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As well as a man might do mother, in modest Latin.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Latin fool?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And she recoiled in hebrew.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In hebrew fool? 'tis Welch.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: All comes to one mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: She can speak English too.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Who told me so much?
Heart and she can speak English, I'll clap to her,
I thought you'd marry me to a stranger.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: You must forgive him, he's so enured to Latin,
He and his tutor, that he hath quite forgotten
To use the Protestant tongue.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.p: 'Tis quickly pardoned forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Tim make amends and kiss her,
He makes towards you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O delicious, one may discover her country by her kissing, 'tis a true saying, there's nothing tastes so sweet as your Welsh mutton: it was reported you could sing.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O rarely Tim, the sweetest British songs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And 'tis my mind I swear before I marry,
I would see all my wives good parts at once,
To view how rich I were.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Thou shalt here sweet music Tim.
Pray forsooth.

lg.l: Cupid is Venus only joy,
But he is a wanton boy,
A very very wanton boy,
He shoots at ladies' naked breasts,
He is the cause of most men's crests,
I mean upon the forehead,
Invisible but horrid,
'Twas he first taught upon the way,
To keep a lady's lips in play.
Why should not Venus chide her son,
For the pranks that he hath done,
The wanton pranks that he hath done?
He shoots his fiery darts so thick,
They hurt poor ladies to the quick,
ah me, with cruel wounding,
His darts are so confounding,
That life and sense would soon decay,
But that he keeps their lips in play.
Can there be any part of bliss,
In a quickly fleeting kiss,
A quickly fleeting kiss,
To ones pleasure, leisures are but waste,
The slowest kiss makes too much haste,
And lose it ere we find it,
The pleasing sport they only know,
That close above and close below.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I would not change my wife for a kingdom,
I can do somewhat too in my own lodging.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Why well said Tim, the bells go merrily,
I love such peals alive, wife lead them in a while,
Here's a strange gentleman desires private conference.
You're welcome sir, the more for your name's sake.
Good Mr. Yellowhammer, I love my name well,
And which a'the Yellowhammers take you descent from,
If I may be so bold with you, which I pray?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The Yellowhammers in Oxfordshire,
Near Abbington.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And those are the best Yellowhammers, and truest bred: I came from thence myself, though now a citizen: I'll be bold with you, you are most welcome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I hope the zeal I bring with me shall deserve it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I hope no less, what is your will sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I understand by rumours, you have a daughter,
Which my bold love shall henceforth title cousin.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I thank you for her sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I heard of her virtues, and other confirmed graces.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: A plaguy girl sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Fame sets her out with richer ornaments,
Than you are pleased to boast of, 'tis done modestly,
I hear she's towards marriage.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You hear truth sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And with a knight in town, sir Walter Whorehound.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The very same sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I am the sorrier for't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The sorrier, why cousin?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis not too far passed is't? It may be yet recalled?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Recalled, why good sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Resolve me in that point ye shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: There's no contract passed.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I am very joyful sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: But he's the man must bed her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: By no means coz, she's quite undone then,
And you'll curse the time that e'er you made the match,
He's an arrant whoremaster, consumes his time and state, — whom in my knowledge he hath kept this 7 years,
Nay coz, another man's wife too.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O abominable!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Maintains the whole house, apparels the husband,
Pays servants wages, not so much, but —

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Worse and worse, and doth the husband know this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Knows? I and glad he may too, 'tis his living,
As other trades thrive, butchers by selling flesh,
Poulters by venting coneys, or the like cous.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What an incomparable wittol's this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Tush, what cares he for that?
Believe me cous, no more than I do.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What a base slave is that?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All's one to him, he feeds and takes his ease,
Was never the man that ever broke his sleep,
To get a child yet by his own confession,
And yet his wife has seven.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What, by sir Walter?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Sir walter's like to keep 'em, and maintain 'em,
In excellent fashion, he dares do no less sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Life has he children too?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Children? Boy's thus high,
In their Cato and Cordelius.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What you jest sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why, one can make a verse,
And is now at Eton college.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O this news has cut into my heart cous.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: It had eaten nearer if it had not been prevented.
One Allwit's wife.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Allwit? 'foot I have heard of him,
He had a girl kursned lately?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I that work did cost the knight above a hundred mark.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I'll mark him for a knave and villain for't,
A thousand thanks and blessings, I have done with him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, this knight will stick by my ribs still,
I shall not lose him yet, no wife will come,
Where'er he woos, I find him still at home, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Well grant all this, say now his deeds are black,
Pray what serves marriage, but to call him back,
I have kept a whore myself, and had a bastard,
By mrs. Anne, in anno
I care not who knows it, he's now a jolly fellow,
Has been twice warden, so may his fruit be,
They were but base begotten, and so was he,
The knight is rich, he shall be my son-in-law,
No matter so the whore he keeps be wholesome,
My daughter takes no hurt then, so let them wed,
I'll have him sweat well ere they go to bed.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How now Maudlin?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: We are all undone, she's gone, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Again, death which way?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Over the houses:
Lay the waterside, she's gone for ever else.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O venturous baggage!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Thieves, thieves, my sister's stolen,
Some thief hath got her:
Oh how miraculously did my father's plate scape,
'Twas all left out tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Besides three chains of pearl and a box of coral.
My sister's gone, let's look at trig-staires for her,
My mother's gone to lay the common-staires,
At puddle-wharf, and at the dock below,
Stands my poor silly father, run sweet tutor, run.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I had been taken brother by eight sergeants,
But for the honest watermen, I am bound to them,
They are the most requitefulest people living,
For as they get their means by gentlemen,
They are still the forwardest to help gentlemen,
You heard how one 'scaped out of the Blackfriars,
But a while since from two or three varlets
Came into the house with all their rapiers drawn,
As if they'd dance the sword-dance on the stage,
With candles in their hands like chandler's ghosts,
Whilst the poor gentleman so pursued and banded,
Was by an honest pair of oars safely landed.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: I love them with my heart for't.
Your first man sir.
Shall I carry you gentlemen with a pair of oars?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: These be the honest fellows,
Take one pair, and leave the rest for her.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Barne-elmes.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: No more brother.
Your first man.
Shall I carry your worship?

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Go, and you honest watermen that stay,
Here's a french-crown for you,
There comes a maid with all speed to take water,
Row her lustily to Barne-elmes after me.
To Barne-elmes, good sir: make ready the boat Sam,
We'll wait below.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: What made you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I found the way more dangerous than I looked for.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Away quick, there's a boat waits for you,
And I'll take water at Pauls-wharf, and overtake you.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Good sir do, we cannot be too safe.

div.stage: Enter sir Walter, Yellowhammer, Tim and tutor.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Life, call you this close keeping?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She was kept under a double lock.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: A double devil.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's a buff sergeant tutor, he'll never were out.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How would you have women locked?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: With padlocks father, the Venetian uses it,
My tutor reads it.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Heart, if she were so locked up, how got she out?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: There was a little hole looked into the gutter,
But who would have dreamed of that?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: A wiser man would.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: He says true father, a wise man for love will seek every hole: my tutor knows it.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Verum poeta dicit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Dicit virgillius father.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Prithee talk of thy gills somewhere else, she's played the Gill with me: where's your wise mother now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Run mad I think, I thought she would have drowned herself, she would not stay for oars, but took a smelt-boat: sure I think she be gone a fishing for her.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: She'll catch a goodly dish of gudgeons now,
Will serve us all to supper.

div.stage: Enter Maudlin drawing Moll by the hair, and watermen.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'll tug thee home by the hair.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Good mistress spare her.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Tend your own business.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You are a cruel mother.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O my heart dies!

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'll make thee an example for all the neighbours daughters.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Farewell life.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: You that have tricks can counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Hold, hold Maudlin.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I have brought your jewel by the hair.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She's here knight.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Forbear or I'll grow worse.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Look on her tutor, she hath brought her from the water like a mermaid, she's but half my sister now, as far as the flesh goes, the rest may be sold to fishwives.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Dissembling cunning baggage.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Impudent strumpet.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Either give over both, or I'll give over:
Why have you used me thus unkind mistress?
Wherein have I deserved?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You talk too fondly sir, we'll take another course and prevent all, we might have don't long since, we'll lose no time now, nor trust to't any longer, tomorrow morn as early as sun rise we'll have you joined.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: O bring me death tonight , love pitying fates,
Let me not see tomorrow up upon the world.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Are you content sir, till then she shall be watched?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Baggage you shall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why father, my tutor and I will both watch in armour.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: How shall we do for weapons?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Take you no care for that, if need be I can send for conquering mettle tutor, never lost day yet, 'tis but at Westminster, I am acquainted with him that keeps the monuments, I can borrow harry the fifth's sword, 'twill serve us both to watch with.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I never was so near my wish, as this chance
Makes me, ere tomorrow noon,
I shall receive two thousand pound in gold,
And a sweet maidenhead
Worth forty.

div.stage: Enter Tuchwood junior with a waterman.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: O thy news splits me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Half drowned, she cruelly tugged her by the hair,
Forced her disgracefully, not like a mother.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: Enough, leave me like my joys,
Sir saw you not a wretched maid pass this way?
Heart villain, is it thou?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yes slave, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: I must break through thee then, there is no stop
That checks my tongue, and all my hopeful fortunes,
That breast excepted, and I must have way.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Sir I believe 'twill hold your life in play.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: Sir you'll gain the heart in my breast at first?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: There is no dealing then, think on the dowry for two thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: O now 'tis quit sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: And being of even hand, I'll play no longer.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: No longer slave?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I have certain things to think on,
Before I dare go further.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.l: But one bout?
I'll follow thee to death, but have't out.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Allwit, his wife, and Davy Dahumma.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A misery of a house.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What shall become of us?

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.p: I think his wound be mortal.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thinkest thou so Davy?
Then am I mortal too, but a dead man Davy,
This is no world for me, whene'er he goes,
I must e'en truss up all, and after him Davy,
A sheet with two knots, and away.

div.stage: Enter sir Walter led in hurt.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.l: O see sir,
How faint he goes, two of my fellows lead him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hyday, my wife's laid down too, here's like to be
A good house kept, when we are altogether down,
Take pains with her good Davy, cheer her up there,
Let me come to his worship, let me come.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Touch me not villain, my wound aches at thee,
Thou poison to my heart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He raves already,
His senses are quite gone, he knows me not,
Look up an't like your worship, heave those eyes,
Call me to mind, is your remembrance lost?
Look in my face, who am I an't like your worship?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: If any thing be worse than slave or villain,
Thou art the man.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Alas his poor worship's weakness,
He will begin to know me by little and little.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: No devil can be like thee.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ah poor gentleman,
Methinks the pain that thou endurest.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Thou knowest me to be wicked for thy baseness
Kept the eyes open still on all my sins,
None knew the dear account my soul stood charged with
So well as thou, yet like hell's flattering angel,
Wouldst never tell me an't, lettest me go on,
And join with death in sleep, that if I had not waked
Now by chance, even by a stranger's pity,
I had everlastingly slept out all hope
Of grace and mercy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now he is worse and worse,
Wife, to him wife, thou wast wont to do good on him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How is't with you sir?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Not as with you,
Thou loathsome strumpet: some good pitying man
Remove my sins out of my sight a little,
I tremble to behold her, she keeps back
All comfort while she stays, is this a time,
Unconscionable woman, to see thee,
Art thou so cruel to the peace of man,
Not to give liberty now, the devil himself
Shows a far fairer reverence and respect
To goodness than thyself, he dares not do this,
But part in time of penitence, hides his face,
When man withdraws from him, he leaves the place,
Hast thou less manners, and more impudence,
Than thy instructor, prithee show thy modesty,
If the least grain be left, and get thee from me,
Thou shouldst be rather locked many rooms hence,
From the poor miserable sight of me ▪
If either love or grace had part in thee.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: He is lost for ever.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Run sweet Davy quickly,
And fetch the children hither, sight of them,
Will make him cheerful straight.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O death! Is this
A place for you to weep? What tears are those?
Get you away with them, I shall fare the worse,
As long as they are a weeping, they work against me,
There's nothing but thy appetite in that sorrow,
Thou weepest for lust, I feel it in the slackness
Of comforts coming towards me,
I was well till thou began'st to undo me,
This shows like the fruitless sorrow of a careless mother
That brings her son with dalliance to the gallows,
And then stands by, and weeps to see him suffer.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.l: There are the children sir, an't like your worship,
Your last fine girl, in troth she smiles,
Look, look, in faith sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O my vengeance, let me for ever hide my cursed face
From sight of those that darkens all my hopes,
And stands between me and the sight of heaven,
Who sees me now, ho to and those so near me,
May rightly say, I am o'ergrown with sin,
Oh how my offences wrestle with my repentance,
It hath scarce breath,
Still my adulterous guilt hovers aloft,
And with her black wings beats down all my prayers.
Ere they be half way up, what's he knows now,
How long I have to live? O what comes then,
My taste grows bitter, the round world, all gall now,
Her pleasing pleasures now hath poisoned me,
Which I exchanged my soul for,
Make way a hundred sighs at once for me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Speak to him nick.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: I dare not, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tell him he hurts his wounds what, with making moan.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Wretched, death of seven.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come let's be talking somewhat to keep him alive
Ah sira Wat, and did my lord bestow that jewel on thee,
For an epistle thou madest in Latin,
Thou art a good forward boy, there's great joy on thee.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: O sorrow!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Heart will nothing comfort him?
If he be so far gone, 'tis time to moan,
Here's pen, and ink, and paper, and all things ready,
Wil't please your worship for to make your will?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: My will? Yes, yes, what else? Who writes apace now?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: That can your man Davy an't like your worship,
A fair, fast, legible hand.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Set it down then:
Inprimis, I bequeath to yonder wittol,
Three times his weight in curses,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: All plagues of body and of mind,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Write them not down Davy.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.p: It is his will, I must.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Together also,
With such a sickness, ten days ere his death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: There's a sweet legacy,
I am almost choked with't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Next I bequeath to that foul whore his wife,
All barrenness of joy, a drought of virtue,
And dearth of all repentance: for her end,
The common misery of an English strumpet,
In French and Dutch, beholding ere she dies
Confusion of her brats before her eyes,
And never shed a tear for it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Where's the knight?
O sir, the gentleman you wounded, is newly departed.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Dead? Lift, lift, who helps me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Let the law lift you now, that must have all,
I have done lifting on you, and my wife too.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: You were best lock yourself close.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Not in my house sir,
I'll harbour no such persons as men-slayers,
Lock yourself where you will.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I know what I do wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: You cannot tell yet,
For having killed the man in his defence,
Neither his life, nor estate will be touched husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away wife, hear a fool, his lands will hang him.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Am I denied a chamber?
What say you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Alas sir, I am one that would have all well,
But must obey my husband. Prithee love
Let the poor gentleman stay, being so sore wounded,
There's a close chamber at one end of the garret
We never use, let him have that I prithee.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We never use, you forget sickness then,
And physic times: is't not a place for easement?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O death! do I hear this with part
Of former life in me? What's the news now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Troth worse and worse, you're like to lose your land
If the law save your life sir, or the surgeon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hark you there wife.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Why how sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir Oliver Kix's wife is new quickened,
That child undoes you sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: All ill at once.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I wonder what he makes here with his consorts?
Cannot our house be private to ourselves,
But we must have such guests? I pray depart sirs,
And take your murderer along with you,
Good he were apprehended ere he go,
Has killed some honest gentleman, send for officers.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I'll soon save you that labour.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I must tell you sir,
You have been somewhat boulder in my house,
Than I could well like of, I suffered you
Till it stuck here at my heart, I tell you truly
I thought you had been familiar with my wife once.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: With me? I'll see him hanged first, I defy him,
And all such gentlemen in the like extremity.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: If ever eyes were open, these are they,
Gamester's farewell, I have nothing left to play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And therefore get you gone sir.

sp.speaker: Davy
sp.l: Of all wittols,
Be thou the head. Thou the grand whore of spitals.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: So, since he's like now to be rid of all,
I am right glad, I am so well rid of him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I knew he durst not stay, when you named officers

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: That stopped his spirits straight,
What shall we do now wife?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: As we were wont to do.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We are richly furnished wife, with householdstuff

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Let's let out lodgings then,
And take a house in the strand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In troth a match wench:
We are simply stocked, with cloth of tissue cushions,
To furnish out bay-windows: push, what not that's quaint
And costly, from the top to the bottom:
Life, for furniture, we may lodge a countess:
there's a close-stool of tawny velvet too,
Now I think on't wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: There's that should be sir,
Your nose must be in every thing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I have done wench,
And let this stand in every gallants chamber,
There's no gamester like a politic sinner,
For whoe'er games, the box is sure a winner.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: O husband, husband, she will die, she will die
There is no sign but death.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: 'Twill be our shame then.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O how she's changed in compass of an hour:

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Ah my poor girl! good faith thou wert too cruel
To drag her by the hair.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: You would have done as much sir,
To curb her of her humour.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: 'Tis curbed sweetly, she catched her bane o'th water.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How now Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Faith busy mother about an epitaph,
Upon my sister's death.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Death! She is not dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No: but she means to be, and that's as good,
And when a thing's done, 'tis done,
You taught me that mother.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What is your tutor doing?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Making one too, in principal pure Latin,
Culled out of Ovid de tristibus.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How does your sister look, is she not changed?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Changed? Gold into white money was never so changed,
As is my sister's colour into paleness.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O here she's brought, see how she looks like death

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Looks she like death, and never a word made yet,
I must go beat my brains against a bedpost,
And get before my tutor.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Speak, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: I hope I shall be well, for I am as sick at heart,
As I can be.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Alas my poor girl,
The doctor's making a most sovereign drink for thee,
The worst ingredience, dissolved pearl and amber,
We spare no cost girl.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Your love comes too late,
Yet timely thanks reward it: what is comfort,
When the poor patient's heart is past relief?
It is no doctors art can cure my grief.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: All is cast away then,
Prithee look upon me cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Sing but a strain or two, thou wilt not think
How 'twill revive thy spirits: strive with thy fit,
Prithee sweet Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: You shall have my good will mother.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Why well said wench.

quote.l: My love and I must part,
Cruel fates, truelove do soonest sever,
Oh, I shall see thee, never, never, never.
O happy is the maid, whose life takes end,
Ere it knows parents frown, or loss of friend.
My love and I must part.

div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Senior with a letter.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O, I could die with music: well sung girl.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: If you call it so, it was.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She plays the swan, and sings herself to death.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: By your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What are you sir? Or what's your business pray?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I may be now admitted, though the brother
Of him your hate pursued, it spreads no further,
Your malice sets in death, does it not sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: In death?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: He's dead: 'twas a dear love to him,
It cost him but his life, that was all sir:
He paid enough, poor gentleman, for his love.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: There's all our ill removed, if she were well now:
Impute not sir, his end to any hate
That sprung from us, he had a fair wound brought that.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: That helped him forward, I must needs confess:
But the restraint of love, and your unkindness,
Those were the wounds, that from his heart drew blood,
But being passed help, let words forget it too:
Scarcely three minutes, ere his eyelids closed,
And took eternal leave of this world's light,
He wrote this letter, which by oath he bound me,
To give to her own hands, that's all my business.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You may perform it then, there she sits.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: O with a following look.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I trust me sir, I think she'll follow him quickly.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Here's some gold,
He willed me to distribute faithfully amongst your servants.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Alas what doth he mean sir?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: How cheer you mistress?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I must learn of you sir.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Here's a letter from a friend of yours,
And where that fails, in satisfaction
I have a sad tongue ready to supply.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How does he, ere I look on't?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Seldom better, has a contented health now.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am most glad on't.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Dead sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: He is: now wife let's but get the girl
Upon her legs again, and to church roundly with her.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: O sick to death he tells me:
How does he after this?

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Faith feels no pain at all, he's dead sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Peace close mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The girl, look to the girl wife.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Moll, daughter, sweet girl speak,
Look but once up, thou shalt have all the wishes of thy heart
That wealth can purchase.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O she's gone for ever, that letter broke her heart.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: As good now then, as let here lie in torment,
And then break it.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O Susan, she thou lovedst so dear, is gone.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: O sweet maid!

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: This is she that helped her still,
I've a reward here for thee

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Take her in,
Remove her from our sight, our shame, and sorrow.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Stay, let me help thee, 'tis the last cold kindness
I can perform for my sweet brother's sake.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: All the whole street will hate us, and the world
Point me out cruel: it is our best course wife,
After we have given order for the funeral,
To absent ourselves, till she be laid in ground.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Where shall we spend that time?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I'll tell thee where wench, go to some private church,
And marry Tim to the rich Brecknock gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Mass a match,
We'll not lose all at once, somewhat we'll catch.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Ho my wives quickened, I am a man for ever,
I think I have bestirred my stumps i'faith:
Run, get your fellows altogether instantly,
Then to the parish-church, and ring the bells.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Upon my love I charge you villain, that you make a bonfire before the door at night.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A bonfire sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: A thwacking one I charge you.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: This is monstrous.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Run, tell a hundred pound out for the gentleman
That gave my wife the drink, the first thing you do.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A hundred pounds sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: A bargain, as our joys grows,
We must remember still from whence it flows,
Or else we prove ungrateful multiplyers:
The child is coming, and the land comes after,
The news of this will make a poor sir Walter.
I have struck it home i'faith.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: That you have marry sir.
But will not your worship go to the funeral
Of both these lovers?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Both, go both together?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I sir, the gentleman's brother will have it so,
'Twill be the pitifullest sight, there's such running,
Such rumours, and such throngs, a pair of lovers
Had never more spectators, more men's pities,
Or women's wet eyes.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: My wife helps the number then?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There's such drawing out of handkerchiefs,
And those that have no handkerchiefs, lift up aprons.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Her parents may have joyful hearts at this,
I would not have my cruelty so talked on,
To any child of mine, for a monopoly.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I believe you sir.
'Tis cast so too, that both their coffins meet,
Which will be lamentable.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Come, we'll see't.

div.stage:
Recorders dolefully playing: enter at one door the coffin of the gentleman, solemnly decked, his sword upon it, attended by many in black, his brother being the chief mourner: at the other door, the coffin of the virgin, with a garland of flowers, with epitapher pined on't,
attended by maids and women: then set them down one right over-against the other, while all the company seem to weep and mourn, there is a sad song in the music-room.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Never could death boast of a richer prize
From the first parent, let the world bring forth
A pair of truer hearts, to speak but truth
Of this departed gentleman, in a brother,
Might by hard censure, be called flattery,
Which makes me rather, silent in his right,
Then so to be delivered to the thoughts,
Of any envious hearer, starved in virtue,
And therefore pining to hear others thrive.
But for this maid, whom envy cannot hurt
With all her poisons, having left to ages,
The true, chaste monument of her living name,
Which no time can deface, I say of her
The full truth freely, without fear of censure
What nature could there shine, that might redeem
Perfection home to woman, but in her
Was fully glorious, beauty set in goodness
Speaks what she was, that jewel so infixed,
There was no want of any thing of life,
To make these virtuous presidents, man and wife.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: Great pity of their deaths.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Never more pity.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It makes a hundred weeping eyes, sweet gossip.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: I cannot think, there's any one amongst you,
In this full fair assembly, maid, man, or wife,
Whose heart would not have sprung with joy and gladness
To have seen their marriage day?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: It would have made a thousand joyful hearts.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Up then a pace, and take your fortunes,
Make these joyful hearts, here's none but friends.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Alive sir? O sweet dear couple.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Nay, do not hinder 'em now, stand from about 'em,
If she be caught again, and have this time,
I'll ne'er plot further for 'em, nor this honest chambermaid
that helped all at a push.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Good sir a pace.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: Hands join now, but hearts for ever,
Which no parent's mood shall sever.
You shall forsake all widows, wives, and maids:
You, lords, knights, gentlemen, and men of trades:
And if in haste, any article misses,
Go interline it with a brace of kisses.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Here's a thing trolled nimbly. Give you joy brother
Were't not better thou shouldst have her,
Than the maid should die?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: To you sweet mistress Bride.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Joy, joy to you both.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Here be your wedding sheets you brought along with you, you may both go to bed when you please too.

sp.speaker: T.i.
sp.p: My joy wants utterance.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Utter all at night than brother.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am silent with delight.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Sister, delight will silence any woman,
But you'll find your tongue again, among maid servants,
Now you keep house, sister.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Never was hour, so filled with joy and wonder.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: To tell you the full story of this chambermaid,
And of her kindness in this business to us,
'Twould ask an hour's discourse: in brief 'twas she,
That wrought it to this purpose cunningly.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: We shall all love her for't.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: See who comes here now.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: A storm, a storm, but we are sheltered for it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I will prevent you all, and mock you thus,
You, and your expectations, I stand happy,
Both in your lives, and your heart's combination.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Here's a strange day again.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: The knights proved villain,
All's come out now, his niece an arrant baggage,
My poor boy Tim, is cast away this morning,
even before breakfast: married a whore
Next to his heart.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: A whore?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: His niece forsooth.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: I think we rid our hands in good time of him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I knew he was passed the best, when I gave him over.
What is become of him pray sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Who the knight? he lies i'th' knights ward now.
Your belly lady begins to blossom, there's no peace for him
His creditors are so greedy.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Mr. Tuchwood, hearest thou this news?
I am so endeared to thee for my wife's fruitfulness,
That I charge you both, your wife and thee,
To live no more asunder for the world's frowns,
I have purse, and bed, and board for you:
Be not afraid to go to your business roundly,
Get children, and I'll keep them.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Prove me, with three at a birth, and thou dar'st now.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Take heed how you dare a man, while you live sir
That has good skill at his weapon.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'foot, I dare you sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Look gentlemen, if ever you say the picture
Of the unfortunate marriage, yonder 'tis.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.p: Nay good sweet Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Come from the university,
To marry a whore in London, with my tutor too?
O tempora! O mors!

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Prithee Tim be patient.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I bought a jade at Cambridge,
I'll let her out to execution tutor,
For eighteen pence a day, or Brainford horseraces,
She'll serve to carry seven miles out of town well.
Where be these mountains? I was promised mountains,
But there's such a mist, I can see none of 'em.
What are become of those two thousand runts?
Let's have about with them in the mean time.
A vengeance runt thee.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Good sweet Tim have patience.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: Flectere si neguro superos acheronta mourbo, mother

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: I think you have married her in logic Tim.
You told me once, by logic you would prove
A whore, an honest woman, prove her so Tim
And take her for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Troth I thank you.
I grant you I may prove another man's wife so,
But not mine own.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: There's no remedy now Tim,
You must prove her so as well as you may.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why then my tutor and I will about her,
As well as we can.
Uxor non est meritrix, ergo falacis.

sp.speaker: W.g.
sp.l: Sir if your logic cannot prove me honest,
There's a thing called marriage, and that makes me honest.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O there's a trick beyond your logic Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I perceive then a woman may be honest according to the English print, when she is a whore in the Latin.
So much for marriage and logic. I'll love her for her wit, I'll pick out my runts there: and for my mountains, I'll mount upon —

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: So fortune seldom deals two marriages
With one hand, and both lucky: the best is,
One feast will serve them both: marry for room,
I'll have the dinner kept in Gold-smithes-hall,
To which kind gallants, I invite you all.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
